name: Davis Bare
phonescreen_details: it was described as "could i go out for beer with this person?" by the person who hired me
take_home_challenge_details: Had to set up your computer with their app, get everthing working and document it . took around 30 hours to complete
whiteboarding_details: was remote; Algorithms using hash/array iteration
notes: 6 interviews total, hardest part was the take home challenge for sure.  Took the most time and effort

name: Earl Sabal
phonescreen_details: Asked about background, behavior, and why First Republic
tech_screen_details: Was asked to talk about solving finding a word that is 7 letters, if you dropped the first letter is still an synonym of the original word, and the dropped letter is an abbreviation of an antonym fo the original word
notes: A DBC Alumni got hired here

name: Joseph Huang
phonescreen_details: Background, team dynamics
notes: AI team is using python scripts

name: Youssef Kholeif
position: Digital Marketing / Software Development graduate scheme
take_home_challenge_details: Presentation on anything of your choice
onsite_details: Just long onsite day with 3 interviews, mixed between cultural and technical. Presentation of your choice, then ended with 4 mini aptitude tests
notes: Amazing company culture and probably the top 3 in the world performance marketing agencies. Only downside was the aptitude test which I was not prepared for.

name: Kaitlyn McPartland
phonescreen_details: Background with Epic software and previous projects
tech_screen_details: Asked technical questions regarding Epic software - how to build certain features, process for troubleshooting specific technical errors
negotiation_details: I negotiate salary and travel per contract, negotiated less travel for most recent contract and slightly higher salary based on my valuation of my previous certifications
notes: As of right now you can only work here as a consultant if you have Epic certifications - they might open up to include Cerner and Meditech in the future

name: Rio Nose
phonescreen_details: Basic background, experience, and more info about the company
take_home_challenge_details: I had to build a science simulation in JavaScript
onsite_details: I interviewed with 4 people, built chess with OOP, explained how I deal with project management
whiteboarding_details: Build chess using OOP concepts
negotiation_details: I received written offer, I negotiated saying how much other students were getting, they upped the offer 8k
notes: Awesome company doing awesome things, with cool people. Will find out more when I start next week.

name: Kayden Maier
phonescreen_details: Background and basic troubleshooting questions
onsite_details: 1 onsite 5 people one whiteboarding
whiteboarding_details: Is this string a Palindrome
negotiation_details: They started at 63 I got them up to 70 + overtime and bonus
notes: Best company I have ever worked for. Highly Highly recommend!!!!

name: Ransom Byers
phonescreen_details: Basic background and interests
tech_screen_details: They have a standard interview called the RPI (Rob's Pairing Interview) that is perfectly suited to DBC grads.
onsite_details: A full day of pairing on one or two projects real projects.
notes: Cloudfoundry is much more technically challenging to apply for than Labs, but the San Francisco Labs office is being deliberately shrunk (IPO related financial decisions). The best bet for a recent DBC grad is to apply for a Labs position in any other city.

name: Mark de Dios
phonescreen_details: Simply checking for alignment of the job spec and the interviewee's past exp and ideals for future work
onsite_details: A couple questions from the engineers about making SQL queries, using an ORM, using a CMS e.g. Wordpress
notes: Conservative company with unpredictable, recursive responsibilities that do not get automatd. The PM threw a very condescending comment about the difference between a full stack engineer and software engineer. 10/10 would not rec

name: George C
phonescreen_details: Basic Culture fit/background questions
tech_screen_details: They Did not have one
take_home_challenge_details: 1 data manipulation (find this data in an array)15min ...1 recursive algorithm 20min....1 dom manipulation(jqueary allowed) 25min... must use es2015
notes: Culture seemed great, Jam room, VR area, free food days

name: Zara Aslam
phonescreen_details: Standard background -- how coding? Projects?
tech_screen_details: 1 hour timed coding challenge as technical phone screen -- Use HTML5 geolocation and weather API to display a user's local weather
notes: Engineering team comprised of all men. I think they were about to hire 1 female engineer but she was still in the interviewing phase. (this was back in January tho)

name: anon
phonescreen_details: Basic getting to know you questions
tech_screen_details: Coding challenge over Google Docs, basic coding comprehension algos
onsite_details: 2 onsite interviews, more technical questions, writing bug reports, solving a couple real problems the company encountered
notes: Great company

name: Nestor Ceron
phonescreen_details: Covered background and exerience. Went deep into how i came around to solve problems that i had in previous jobs
onsite_details: I was interview buy the whole team that I am currently working with along with the manager. More basic background questions and some technical.
notes: Great company culture.

name: Frida Sjöholm
phonescreen_details: Tell us your background, interests and recent projects
tech_screen_details: Iterating on the take home challenge, creating new features
take_home_challenge_details: I was given two days to complete a email design with tracking, styling and tests
onsite_details: Meeting with 5 different parts of the team for different parts of the interview, mainly technincal but some q's about fit
whiteboarding_details: Algorithm
notes: Great experience, great company!

name: Rio Nose
phonescreen_details: Asked if I know what inner join is, if I know PHP
tech_screen_details: Asked about indexing, caching
take_home_challenge_details: Use HelloSign API
onsite_details: Code reviews, schema design, SQL queries, HTTP verbs
whiteboarding_details: schema designs
notes: HelloSign is an amazing company. I worked there previously. Recruiter and engineering manager called me to let me know that they didn't have the resources to make sure I had good support and mentoring as a junior so they couldn't hire me at the time. Very positive experience and friendly people as I remembered. 10/10 would recommend working at this company. Best place I've worked so far.

name: anon
onsite_details: My onsite was two full days at Mapbox. I was tasked with a project (which I worked on with others on my team) and spent my additional time meeting with others in the company for show and tells. At the end of my time, I presented my findings.
notes: I absolutely love working at Mapbox. I love going to work every single day. We are hiring! Check our job board!

name: Mike Tarkington
phonescreen_details: Asked about my background, goals, why I wanted the position. Told me about the role and the take home assignment challenge.
take_home_challenge_details: I was given a week to complete a challenge with a very specific set of instructions on how to use the Datadog platform as if I were a client developer.  The challenge involved very basic usage of Python, creation of a Linux virtual machine, creating a small app that could be monitored by the Datadog agent.  There was a lot of technical writing for step by step explanation of the process and statistal results.
onsite_details: My main interviews were not onsite because the role is remote but I met with 5 people over the course of 2.5 hours using video conferencing software.  It started with two pairs of engineers on the team, one being a team lead and the other being a senior Solutions Engineer.  The discussion with the pairs was not very technical but we did touch on a few topics in the natural flow of conversation.  We were mostly getting to know eachother and I told them about my background and specifically how past experiences yielded transferable skills into this role.  The final step was a 1 hour techincal challenge with a senior software engineer.
whiteboarding_details: The main challenge was over a shared code editor with compiler.  It involved a problem similar to the Roman Numerals challenge.  After solving the initial problem, there was a technical discussion about alorithm time and space complexity, edge cases, test driven development, and error handling.  It's important to solve the problem but even more important to be able to talk your way through the solution and then demonstrate knowledge of fundamental computer science concepts and software development conventions.
notes: I know other people have had varying rates of progress for their interview timeline, but it's worth mentioning that it took about two months with a lot of delays.  That said, it was the holiday season and there were some major events taking place in the company.  Just don't be surprised if you need to be a little patient.  Everyone I met was very friendly and professional.  Overall great experience and I'm thrilled to work with them!

name: Rebecca Orr
phonescreen_details: Behavioral
take_home_challenge_details: Build a gif searching app using the giphy api
onsite_details: 1 onsite, 4 1 hour interviews. 2 technical, 1 product/ux, 1 beahvioral/cultural
whiteboarding_details: Build out the flow for a school election system (everyone can vote once for each position (pres, vp, secretary, etc)). After basic crudflow diagramed, asked to whiteboard networking calls using callbacks. Other technical was a comprehensive ask about iOS/cocoa/architecure and design patterns
notes: I love working at Eaze. Please reach out if you're interested, we're hiring! Looking for node/react peeps.

name: Robert Turner
notes: I returned to the company I left for DBC, thus my lack of interviews, etc.This company does not know how to handle tech unfortunately and I wouldn't recommend working here. I'll be moving on before too long.

name: Jaime Rios
phonescreen_details: In-depth questions about success mindset practices
onsite_details: It was a great culture fit, CEO and I were vibing.
notes: I was sold

name: Alex Carroll
phonescreen_details: Basic background and Experience
tech_screen_details: 4 algorithms and some SQL questons
onsite_details: 1 onsite, 5 people, whiteboarding, sql reading challenge, background fit
negotiation_details: Witheld my desired number at each interview and got initial offer that fit my number and accepted. Got a call when the written offer was ready to sign that they raised the offer 10%. Recurly is great to work for.
notes: Know the position day to day activities. Look it up if you dont know. Also be ready to piviot on the position if you can. Just get in and take the experiance and skip the interview grind. The initial position I was interviewed for went to another person, but I was able to piviot because I was open from the get go. Also did 3 months of grinding after camp to prep for interview with algos and projects and it paid off.

name: Yaritza Perez
phonescreen_details: Discussed knowlege and when through and algorithm
tech_screen_details: basic javascript iterating through arrays
notes: let you know about it later

name: Dharini Murugaprabhu
phonescreen_details: Solved Logic puzzle and general conversation about experience
tech_screen_details: Algorithm code challenge and new logic puzzles
take_home_challenge_details: Full stack app development using Rails and JS, focused on front-end
onsite_details: Three rounds of technical inteview and chat with CEO
whiteboarding_details: Basic JS, Rails joins, DB schema

name: Katie O'Neill
take_home_challenge_details: We were provided an API with a word list and needed to create a hangman word game. They were very open to creativity and we could create the game as a web app, mobile app, or command line app.
onsite_details: There was a one hour culture fit interview and a two hour technical interview. In the tech interview we presented our take home challenge and then coded extra features on the spot as requested by the interviewers.

name: Benjamin Acevedo
phonescreen_details: Did not have a phone screen.
onsite_details: Two soft interviews. One with the team discussing e-sports and the brand opportunities. The second with the SVP's of product and markeiting and talked about plans and roadmap for the next year.
notes: NetGear hires everyone on a contract basis for the first 30-90 days. Much of their roles are filled from within. They promote from within regularly.

name: Kayden Maier
phonescreen_details: Backround info and programing problem i've solved
onsite_details: 1 on site 5 interviews one of which was Whiteboarding
whiteboarding_details: Is this string a Palindrome
negotiation_details: they offered 90 I wanted 100 we met at 96
notes: Not a great company for a first time job in Tech. They need someone with a few years experience

name: Robbie Santos
notes: Our acquiring company, Porch, is in Seattle and the Smith team is located in Sunnyvale. Having the support of a bigger organization while being able to hang on to that start-up-move-fast environment is great. I am very thankful for this opportunity to work as a legit full stack developer

name: Vilde Vevatne
tech_screen_details: Talked about my coding experience and background and solved an algorithm.
take_home_challenge_details: Build a Pinterest clone with infinite scrolling and treating a given json object as an API response.
onsite_details: 3 technical interviews. Being asked to solve tightly scoped problems that were highly applicable to the actual job. Had a lunch with an employee to evaluate culture fit.
whiteboarding_details: Find pinnable images on any given webpage. Iterate through an object and returning information.
notes: Pinterest is in many ways a great company, however the apprenticeship could be better structured.

name: Jay Naidu
phonescreen_details: Asked what I know about the company, why I would be a good fit
onsite_details: 2 interviews; first was about my prior work experience and education, second had behavioral questions
notes: Relatively new company (purchased by General Motors last year), great workplace culture, conveniently located near me, working with self-driving cars

name: Jessica Forchione
phonescreen_details: General convo about experience, why I wanted the job, etc.
tech_screen_details: Multiple choice test on coding questions
take_home_challenge_details: cannot provide details
onsite_details: Culture, skills, presentation
notes: Salesforce is amazing!

name: Chester Hoang
phonescreen_details: Architectural UI questions. What to watchout for when building a web app.
tech_screen_details: Algorithm Question. Stairs
onsite_details: Met with 3 people. SQL Queries, HTML/CSS Architecture, Big(O)
negotiation_details: Couldn't negotiate Salary, but received more equity.
notes: Startup Culture is important. Make sure you ask about it during the interview process.

name: Ellie Bahadori
phonescreen_details: Standard phone screen, looking for culture fit, engagement about company, etc.
tech_screen_details: There was a product phone screen, which involved being given a business problem and brainstorming ways to solve it
take_home_challenge_details: Smaller version of real code in production, asked to add some features with test coverage
onsite_details: 4-5 interviews, which included pair programming, a technical exercise, meeting with business partners, engineer leadership, etc.
negotiation_details: Strong initial offer, did not negotiate
notes: Stitch Fix is incredible. Everyone is willing to share knowledge, and you're surrounded by people who are brilliant at what they do. Amazing leadership, strong engineers, and an astoundingly positive work culture.

name: anon
phonescreen_details: Standard Google Questions
tech_screen_details: Boltzmann Machine Explanation
onsite_details: Standard machine learning questions, beginning with naive bayes classifiers, discussion regarding tensor flow, neural networks and NLP.
negotiation_details: 130k + 50k sign on bonus + 80k in stock - negotiated vs Microsoft Salary
notes: Study hard

name: Hayden Langelier
phonescreen_details: Get to know me and wanted to know about my dev experience

name: Joe Hiner
phonescreen_details: background, expectations. second phone interview including technical questions
tech_screen_details: Automotive focus. Some cultural/behavioral questions

negotiation_details: I was urged to began the negotiation process with a base salary number. Their offer was about 95% of that base salary which I accepted.
notes: Super cool company. Very happy. Thank you DBC! Thank you SarSar!

name: Dominique Crowther
tech_screen_details: Asked to talk about one of my projects then some technical Javascript questions involving Promises and higher-order functions

notes: Technical Interviewer seemed stressed about something and checked out. It was very off-putting.

name: anon
phonescreen_details: General conversation & basic scripting question
tech_screen_details: String parsing question
onsite_details: Cultural fit, basic coding
whiteboarding_details: Implement left join, Monadic SQL Parser, using a dictionary to find the most popular word
notes: Terrible company, seems to be chaotic, clear lack of direction.

name: anon
phonescreen_details: General conversation & basic scripting question
tech_screen_details: A couple simple coding questions
take_home_challenge_details: You had to find the challenge in the js console to solve the challenge. This was super fun.
onsite_details: Only with the CEO of company (super small company)
negotiation_details: Negotiated from small amount to slightly bigger, small amount
notes: Terrible experience, terrible company, pay scale not worth the trouble. Highly do not recommend.

name: Chinmay Banker
phonescreen_details: Introductory - "Tell us about yourself", "have you heard about us?", "do you know what we do?"
onsite_details: 2 rounds - 1 technicsal, 1 with CEO
whiteboarding_details: Draw database schemas, explain how servers and clients communicate, what do JSON properties look like, server requests and their contents, how do servers handle excessive requests, how can you scale DBs. On computer, was asked to create a rails app simulating a pet shelter - 45 mins, googling was allowed.
notes: The company has a great product, the teams that i interviewed with were great as well. However, my interview with the CEO left a bad taste in my mouth. He spoke as if he did not believe bootcamp grads deserve an opportunity. Very condescening and rude from the moment i sat down. I would not have accepted an offer even if i got one because after the CEO interview I had doubts about his leadership qualities.

name: anon
phonescreen_details: Only technical phone screen (see next tab)
tech_screen_details: Questions about API design, HTTP, request/response and networking, Linux scripting
take_home_challenge_details: Given a set of constraints, build an API service. Design details intentionally left open to evaluate the candidate's design decisions.
onsite_details: ~4 hours interviewing with team members with technical (programming and design) and behavioral questions.
whiteboarding_details: A data manipulation and storage exercise.
notes: The interview process was positive. However, I can't say the same thing about the work environment. They claim a culture of diversity, inclusion and empathy, as well as a humanitarian-oriented mission, but while working there I experienced a toxic environment, a complete lack of transparency from management and no real engagement in doing good for the Earth.

name: Renan Souza
notes: The interview was made through video skype and we talked about my skills and what the company needed. After they showed my two projects one easy and one a little hard to choose and I select the most challenging one and explained how I would make the app

name: Jen Young
phonescreen_details: with recruiter, basic background questions, basic API knowledge
onsite_details: 2 rounds of onsite interviews: First interview was 4 hours with recruiter and 4 other people with some technical questions; 2nd interview with COO, CEO, hiring manager and recruiter again
whiteboarding_details: Talked through the game of life problem and drew out some diagrams but didn't actually solve the problem, basic API calls in cURL, reverse string
negotiation_details: I negotiated with the VP who was a freaking shark and would not recommend going up against her again
notes: the process was quick once we both realized how well i fit into the company

name: Jennifer Shopsin
phonescreen_details: Cultural fit, asked about who I would give as a reference, what they would rate me from 1 to 10 and why
tech_screen_details: Review a project of your choice and add a feature together with the interviewer, I did not complete the added feature, but did show understanding of Rails, React and JS
onsite_details: 1 cultural fit interview with hiring manger and 2 technical interviews
whiteboarding_details: Given a nested hash or object, output a string of html based on the value of each key
negotiation_details: Negotiated slightly higher salary after explanation of my added value from my background
notes: They moved incredibly quickly (1 week turnaround, plus 1 week offer deadline) I felt that they really valued my time and were extremely pleasant throughout the process. There are even 3 other DBC grads in my team.

name: Amber Nash
phonescreen_details: Simple personality check
tech_screen_details: No phone tech screen
take_home_challenge_details: Utilizing Datadog interface, command line heavy, fairly simple save for running into bugs.
onsite_details: 2 interviews with two people in each. Focussing on your experience/why you think you'd be a good fit.
whiteboarding_details: Was remote - As a woman, my interviewer was changed to a woman outside of what would have been my team with higher standards, and a request for a more complex output than my male counterparts. Completed a data structure problem with some guidance, but failed the interview.
notes: They were really nice. While their treatment of women is shaky, I think they'd be a good company to work for.

name: Andrea Scott
phonescreen_details: Personality check, pretty minimal because I was a referral from the hiring manager.
take_home_challenge_details: My takehome challenge was a product-management case study, not a coding challenge. It was challenging, but not terrible.
onsite_details: I did two on-site interviews: one to present my case study, and another that was about 4 hours of interviews with team members and key stakeholders.
whiteboarding_details: Whiteboarding to describe a data model and potential solution to a business use case.
negotiation_details: Negotiated a larger RSU grant than was offered.
notes: This company is really amazing and was incredibly transparent during the hiring process. It may have been easier for me since I was referred by the person who is now my boss.

name: Hawken Ritter
phonescreen_details: Standard background and behavior questions

name: anon
phonescreen_details: 1st round was pretty standard behavioral, 2nd round was a phone screen with the director of engineering.
tech_screen_details: Ruby on Rails database access methods, implementing a cache, system design, checking for duplicates in a string.
take_home_challenge_details: Determing whether Cuboids overlapped using Ruby.
onsite_details: Panel interviews, you'll meet everyone on the team.
whiteboarding_details: Counter clockwise matrix rotation. System design without a database.

name: Eric Yang
phonescreen_details: Basic background and Experience
tech_screen_details: DOM manipulation knowledge, and React stuff
onsite_details: 1 onsite, 5 people, whiteboarding
whiteboarding_details: Find most commonly appearing words, and create a summary of an article

name: Dawson Graham
phonescreen_details: General conversation around experience, goals, culture fit, etc
tech_screen_details: Not as difficult of problems as I had expected from Google. Biggest piece of advice: KNOW THE TREES (BST, Heaps, Tries are most popular)
take_home_challenge_details: I completed a take-home challenge for StitchFix in a separate application. It was for a QA Automation role so they had me fix incorrect test specs in the web app they sent over, implement new tests, and add a new feature (with tests) to the sample web app. The app just took submission of an excel file with items and associated prices, then did simple stuff with it.
onsite_details: Did an onsite for Skillz in separate application. 45 minutes to build a sample animal shelter CRUD app with 3-4 separate pages, about 4-5 use cases, and the computer they provide you doesn't have autosave enabled in sublime :(
whiteboarding_details: Highly suggest App Academy's 10X program. I took it over the month of October and every single day we practiced whiteboarding in front of others. Any questions or confusion about Big O regarding time and space complexities will be completely satisfied and easily understood by the end. They drill in great algorithm optimization techniques to increase performance (reduce Big O) and they also provide a great high-level view of what's going on outside of just the code, and how programs, machines, and network/internet connect and work full circle.

name: Ibraheem Abdul-Malik
take_home_challenge_details: Build a hangman game in any language using a REST API
onsite_details: 2 hours technical, 1 hour cultural
whiteboarding_details: Live coding of the coding challenge including bug fixes and adding features

take_home_challenge_details: You can have a take home, but I opted in an over the phone challenge vs take home
onsite_details: ~4 hours. Interviewed with 7 individuals. Very positive experience. Very nice, smart people. Company is doing super hot.
whiteboarding_details: Map out an contrived api (i.e. a weight scale that is linked to the cloud and what a potential api could look like)

take_home_challenge_details: Take a dataset and create some data visualization to go along with the data set

take_home_challenge_details: From the UX wireframes provided build this thing and discuss approach
onsite_details: 3hrs. Met with lead product designer, principle UX architect, Sr. QA manager and Hiring Manager. Experience was really good. I was great to see so many facinating products that are designed with autodesk software.

name: anon
phonescreen_details: Solving a business problem
take_home_challenge_details: Add features to an existing app.

name: Jennifer Shopsin
phonescreen_details: Cultural Fit, basic get to know you questions
tech_screen_details: asked about a JS callback function, given code with a function call and it's expected output, right the code to make the given calls work as expected
onsite_details: Very long, 4 seperate interviews + lunch, 1 cultural fit interview with manager discussing a project and the group dynamics, 1 data structures algorithm question, 1 html + css challenge, and a 2 hour coding challenge to make a single page app (90 minutes of coding and 30 minutes of reviewing the code)
whiteboarding_details: everything was done on my personal computer

name: Kevin Cai
tech_screen_details: Algorithm code challenge and some behavial questions
onsite_details: One hour algorithm with a senior sofeware engineer and one hour behavial questions with a hire manager
whiteboarding_details: Given an array of strings and return an array with sub-array of anagrams

name: Dillon Arevalo
phonescreen_details: Asked a few general questions followed by a quick live coding and coding question session. Answered question about closure and did a quick algo (take repeating letters out of word)
tech_screen_details: see phone screen. it was kinda both
take_home_challenge_details: Algorithm challenge. Word search. Done before phone screen and I don't think it's standard. I did on because I applied through other DBC alum working there i think.
onsite_details: had 2 onsites. First one was 3 hours long with 4 interviews. Did some quick TDD, then some JS designing of a module that used callbacks and seemed to be testing scope above much else. Then had a HTML, CSS, and JS about designing a visual component. last interview that day was personality/culture interview. Interviewer was a scrum manager and seemed really grumpy. never smiled. put me off a little. Everyone else was super friendly and nice. Second onsite was for a more specific team and we did a simple algorithm, talked over my resume, and then I talked to the team lead about culture things and went in depth on my experience and resume.
whiteboarding_details: see general onsite experience section.

name: Sam Leiken
tech_screen_details: 45 minute standard technical interview
whiteboarding_details: There were 3 back to back whiteboarding interviews: write an encoder and a decoder. map telephone numbers to all possible words. something about binary trees that I forget

name: Rio Nose
onsite_details: Asked me to look at some code and what I knew about certain topics.

phonescreen_details: Very basic cultural/experience questions

name: Danielle Glass
take_home_challenge_details: The interface was incredibly difficult to deal with. Additionally the challenges themselves(2 of them) had nothing to do with Javascript, HTML or CSS which is what I was told the position was for.

name: Jane Willborn

tech_screen_details: One algorithm (sorry I can't remember! but I think it was JS), a simple CSS challenge (put things in four corners of the screen I think?), and a general front-end CS quiz

tech_screen_details: They use Triplebyte's standardized quiz, but it's like... over an hour of questions in everything from Python to C++ to theory to everything. Good for studying from; ridiculous for an interview

name: Danielle Glass
